definition[0]: to think that something is true, although you do not have definite proof
example[0]: It seems reasonable to assume that the book was written around 70 AD.
example[1]: I think we can safely assume that interest rates will go up again soon.
example[2]: Let us assume for a moment that we could indeed fire her. Should we?
example[3]: When it got to midnight and Paul was still not back, I began to assume the worst.
example[4]: I didn’t see your car, so I assumed you’d gone out.
example[5]: The rest of the system is assumed to be functioning well.
note[5]: somebody/something is assumed to be (doing) something
explanation[0]: In more formal English, you say it is assumed that something is true
example[6]: It is assumed that the person is innocent
definition[1]: to start to have a particular quality or appearance
example[7]: These relationships assume great importance in times of crisis.
example[8]: The problem is beginning to assume massive proportions.
definition[2]: to be based on the idea that something else is correct
example[9]: Coen’s economic forecast assumes a 3.5% growth rate.
example[10]: The theory assumes that both labour and capital are mobile.
